items.title: Appendix A: Glossary of AI Terms for Designers
items.content:
# **Appendix A: Glossary of AI Terms for Designers**

- Algorithm: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
- Bias (in AI): Systematic errors in AI outputs that disadvantage certain groups, typically resulting from biased training data.
- Context window: The amount of text an AI can consider at once when generating responses.
- Deep learning: A subset of machine learning using neural networks with many layers.
- Fine-tuning: Additional training on specific data to specialize a general-purpose model.
- Generative AI: AI systems that generate new content (text, images, audio, code) rather than just analyzing existing content.
- Hallucination: When an AI produces confident-sounding but incorrect or fabricated information.
- Inference: Using a trained model to make predictions or generate outputs on new data.
- Large Language Model (LLM): AI systems trained on massive text datasets to understand and generate natural language.
- Machine learning (ML): AI systems that learn from data rather than being explicitly programmed.
- Model: A trained AI system that can make predictions or generate outputs based on learned patterns.
- Natural Language Processing (NLP): AI technology for understanding and generating human language.
- Neural network: A computing system inspired by biological neural networks, the foundation of most modern AI.
- Prompt: The input given to an AI system to guide its output.
- Prompt engineering: The practice of crafting effective prompts to get better results from AI systems.
- Reinforcement learning: Training AI through trial and error with rewards and penalties.
- Supervised learning: Training AI with labeled examples where correct answers are known.
- Temperature: A parameter controlling randomness in AI outputs-higher temperature means more varied results.
- Token: A unit of text that LLMs process-roughly equivalent to a word or word piece.
- Training: The process of teaching an AI system by exposing it to data.
- Transformer: The neural network architecture underlying most modern LLMs.
- Unsupervised learning: Training AI to find patterns in data without labeled examples.

items.title: Appendix B: Tool Comparison Matrix
items.content:
# **Appendix B: Tool Comparison Matrix**

## **Language Models**

ChatGPT (OpenAI): Strong general-purpose capabilities, code generation, plugin ecosystem. Good for brainstorming, writing, code help.

Claude (Anthropic): Strong analysis and nuance, longer context window, thoughtful on sensitive topics. Good for research analysis, detailed writing.

Gemini (Google): Multimodal capabilities, Google integration. Good for tasks involving multiple content types.

## **Image Generators**

Midjourney: High aesthetic quality, strong for artistic and design imagery. Access via Discord. Good for moodboards, visual concepts.

DALL-E: Good general-purpose generation, accessible via ChatGPT. Good for quick concept visualization.

Stable Diffusion: Open source, runs locally, highly customizable. Good for those wanting technical control.

## **Design-Integrated AI**

Figma AI: Built into Figma for design suggestions, auto-layout, and content generation.

Adobe Firefly: Adobe's AI image generation integrated with Creative Cloud.

Various plugins: Numerous Figma, Sketch, and other plugins adding AI capabilities.

## **Research and Analysis**

Various tools emerge regularly for research transcription, analysis, and synthesis. Evaluate current options against your specific needs.

items.title: Appendix C: Sample Prompts Library
items.content:
# **Appendix C: Sample Prompts Library**

## **Research Prompts**

_'Summarize this user interview transcript, focusing on: main pain points, key feature requests, surprising insights, and notable quotes.'_

_'Given these 10 interview summaries, identify the top 5 recurring themes across participants.'_

_'Generate 10 interview questions to explore users' habits and frustrations with \[product type\].'_

## **Ideation Prompts**

_'Brainstorm 10 different approaches to solve \[specific problem\]. Make each approach distinctly different.'_

_'What assumptions are we making about how users should complete \[task\]? For each, suggest alternatives.'_

_'How do other industries solve the problem of \[challenge\]? Give examples from at least 3 different domains.'_

## **Visual Design Prompts**

_'\[For Midjourney\] Modern mobile app interface for \[purpose\], \[style\] aesthetic, \[color description\], \[mood\]'_

_'\[For Midjourney\] Set of minimalist icons for \[app type\] including \[icon list\], consistent \[style\] style'_

## **UX Writing Prompts**

_'Suggest 5 different labels for a button that \[action\]. Tone should be \[description\].'_

_'Write an error message for when \[situation\]. Should clearly explain problem and suggest next steps.'_

_'Generate realistic placeholder content for \[element type\] including \[variations needed\].'_

## **Code Generation Prompts**

_'Generate HTML and CSS code that replicates this mobile app screen design. Use Tailwind CSS. Make responsive.'_

_'Generate a React component based on these specifications: \[specs\]. Include all states and variations.'_

## **Review Prompts**

_'Review this design against Nielsen's 10 usability heuristics. For each, rate compliance and identify violations.'_

_'Evaluate this design for accessibility: color contrast, text size, touch targets, screen reader compatibility.'_

items.title: Appendix D: Career Transition Checklist
items.content:
# **Appendix D: Career Transition Checklist**

Use this checklist to prepare for transitioning to an AI-enhanced UX role:

## **Skills Development**

- Achieved working proficiency with at least one major LLM (ChatGPT or Claude)
- Experimented with at least one AI image generator (Midjourney, DALL-E, or similar)
- Learned basic prompt engineering techniques
- Understand fundamental AI/ML concepts
- Familiar with AI features in primary design tools
- Basic HTML/CSS knowledge for evaluating generated code
- Understanding of AI ethics and responsible design principles

## **Portfolio Updates**

- At least one case study showing AI-enhanced design process
- Documentation of how AI tools were used and what judgment was applied
- If applicable, case study of designing AI-powered features
- Personal project demonstrating AI tool capabilities

## **Interview Preparation**

- Can articulate specific examples of using AI in design work
- Have nuanced perspective on AI capabilities and limitations
- Ready to discuss ethical considerations of AI in design
- Can answer 'How do you think AI will change design?'
- Researched target companies' use of AI

## **Ongoing Development**

- Set up regular learning time for AI tool experimentation
- Following AI/UX thought leaders and communities
- Sharing learnings with peers or through writing
- Tracking AI tool developments and new capabilities
